Message.Issue: Provide an overridable implementation of Dispose(bool) on 'DataBaseProvider' or mark the type as sealed. A call to Dispose(false) should only clean up native resources. A call to Dispose(true) should clean up both managed and native resources.

Message.TypeName: Review SQL queries for security vulnerabilities
Message.Issue: The query string passed to 'SqlCommand.SqlCommand(string, SqlConnection)' in 'DataBaseProvider.CallStoredProcedure(string, Dictionary<string, object>, string[])' could contain the following variables 'procName'. If any of these variables could come from user input, consider using a stored procedure or a parameterized SQL query instead of building the query with string concatenations.
Modify 'DataBaseProvider.Dispose()' so that it calls Dispose(true), then calls GC.SuppressFinalize on the current object instance ('this' or 'Me' in Visual Basic), and then returns.

Message.TypeName: Review SQL queries for security vulnerabilities
Message.Issue: The query string passed to 'SqlCommand.SqlCommand(string, SqlConnection)' in 'DataBaseProvider.InsertLineToTable(string, Dictionary<string, object>)' could contain the following variables 'DataBaseProvider.SafeSqlLiteral(comString)'. If any of these variables could come from user input, consider using a stored procedure or a parameterized SQL query instead of building the query with string concatenations.

Implement IDisposable on 'MasterFinance' because it creates members of the following IDisposable types: 'DataBaseProvider'. If 'MasterFinance' has previously shipped, adding new members that implement IDisposable to this type is considered a breaking change to existing consumers.

Message.TypeName: Provide correct arguments to formatting methods
Message.Issue: Method 'MasterFinance.DepositPayDogovor(int, int)' calls 'string.Format(string, object, object)' with a format string that contains an unexpected character '"}"' at index '55'. The provided format string is: '"Pay deposit exception. Recieved code {0}. Error text \'{}\'."'

Rule.Name: Implement IDisposable correctly
Rule.Description: All IDisposable types should implement the Dispose pattern correctly.
Rule.Resolution: Modify {0} so that it calls Dispose(true), then calls GC.SuppressFinalize on the current object instance ('this' or 'Me' in Visual Basic), and then returns.

Provide an overridable implementation of Dispose(bool) on {0} or mark the type as sealed. A call to Dispose(false) should only clean up native resources. A call to Dispose(true) should clean up both managed and native resources.

Rule.TypeName: Provide correct arguments to formatting methods
Rule.Name: Provide correct arguments to formatting methods
Rule.Description: Provide the correct number of arguments to String.Format calls.
Rule.Resolution: Method {0} calls {1} with a format string that contains an unexpected character '{2}' at index '{3}'. The provided format string is: '{4}'

Rule.TypeName: Review SQL queries for security vulnerabilities
Rule.Name: Review SQL queries for security vulnerabilities
Rule.Description: A SQL command string built from user input is vulnerable to SQL injection attacks. Microsoft SQL Server and other database servers support stored procedures and parameterized SQL queries, which reduce the risk of injection attacks.
Rule.Resolution: The query string passed to {0} in {1} could contain the following variables {2}. If any of these variables could come from user input, consider using a stored procedure or a parameterized SQL query instead of building the query with string concatenations.

Rule.Name: Types that own disposable fields should be disposable
Rule.Description: Types that declare disposable members should also implement IDisposable. If the type does not own any unmanaged resources, do not implement a finalizer on it.
Rule.Resolution: Implement IDisposable on {0} because it creates members of the following IDisposable types: {1}. If {0} has previously shipped, adding new members that implement IDisposable to this type is considered a breaking change to existing consumers.
